articles.headline: Hundreds Released From Diamond Princess Cruise Ship in Japan
articles.snippet: Coronavirus quarantine over, passengers ventured off into the port city of Yokohama and beyond amid deep concerns among health experts and the announcement of two deaths.
articles.abstract: Coronavirus quarantine over, passengers ventured off into the port city of Yokohama and beyond amid deep concerns among health experts and the announcement of two deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOKOHAMA, Japan — Hundreds of passengers walked off a coronavirus-stricken cruise ship Wednesday after getting the all-clear from the Japanese authorities, but the scene that greeted them as their feet touched solid ground for the first time in weeks suggested that some found the assurances less than reassuring.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and Eimi Yamamitsu

articles.headline: Your Doorbell Camera Spied on You. Now What?
articles.snippet: Amazon’s popular Ring security cameras have gaping security holes. Here’s how to protect yourself.
articles.abstract: Amazon’s popular Ring security cameras have gaping security holes. Here’s how to protect yourself.
articles.lead_paragraph: Has there ever been a tech product more polarizing than Ring?

articles.headline: California Governor Declares Homeless Crisis ‘a Disgrace’
articles.snippet: Vulnerable to the charge that the problem has exploded under Democratic rule, Gov. Gavin Newsom pleaded with legislators to take action.
articles.abstract: Vulnerable to the charge that the problem has exploded under Democratic rule, Gov. Gavin Newsom pleaded with legislators to take action.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — With tens of thousands of people living on the streets of California, the homelessness crisis has become the state’s defining issue. For Gov. Gavin Newsom, the emergency had become so dire that he devoted his entire State of the State address on Wednesday to the 150,000 Californians without homes.

articles.headline: The 11 Criminals Granted Clemency by Trump Had One Thing in Common: Connections
articles.snippet: The process bypassed the formal procedures used by past presidents and was driven instead by friendship, fame, personal empathy and a shared sense of persecution.
articles.abstract: The process bypassed the formal procedures used by past presidents and was driven instead by friendship, fame, personal empathy and a shared sense of persecution.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Early Tuesday morning, Bernard B. Kerik’s telephone rang. On the line was David Safavian, a friend and fellow former government official who like Mr. Kerik was once imprisoned for misconduct. Mr. Safavian had life-changing news.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, J. David Goodman, Michael Rothfeld and Elizabeth Williamson

articles.headline: Warren Leads an Onslaught of Attacks, Zeroing In on Bloomberg
articles.snippet: The sharp exchanges in the Nevada debate reflected the urgency of the moment as Michael Bloomberg, in his first presidential debate, was repeatedly criticized in personal terms.
articles.abstract: The sharp exchanges in the Nevada debate reflected the urgency of the moment as Michael Bloomberg, in his first presidential debate, was repeatedly criticized in personal terms.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The Democratic presidential candidates turned on one another in scorching and personal terms in a debate on Wednesday night, with two of the leading candidates, Senator Bernie Sanders and Michael R. Bloomberg, forced onto the defensive repeatedly throughout the evening.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: A Police State With an Islamist Twist: Inside Hifter’s Libya
articles.snippet: Khalifa Hifter, the military ruler of eastern Libya, is trying to take over the entire country. To see what that would look like, we paid a rare visit to the part he already controls.
articles.abstract: Khalifa Hifter, the military ruler of eastern Libya, is trying to take over the entire country. To see what that would look like, we paid a rare visit to the part he already controls.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — The field marshal stares from billboards into the wreckage of the Libyan city of Benghazi. His uniform is festooned with epaulets and honors, even as the civil war he is waging has stalled into a bloody stalemate.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Ivor Prickett

articles.headline: Billions of Targets on His Back, Bloomberg Joins the Debate Fray
articles.snippet: Making his debut onstage, he was greeted by forceful challenges from Elizabeth Warren and the rest of the Democratic field.
articles.abstract: Making his debut onstage, he was greeted by forceful challenges from Elizabeth Warren and the rest of the Democratic field.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg bobbed behind his lectern, as if the motion might deliver him somewhere more comfortable. He blinked, then blinked some more. He appeared unsteady — for all the preparation his billions might buy him — on questions of race and gender that could not have come as a surprise.

articles.headline: Far-Right Shooting Shatters an Already Fragile Sense of Security in Germany
articles.snippet: The attack showed that no part of the country is immune to the potential for violence fueled by anti-immigrant hatred.
articles.abstract: The attack showed that no part of the country is immune to the potential for violence fueled by anti-immigrant hatred.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANAU, Germany — Hanau, a small city in western Germany, considered itself a melting pot, an island of tolerance. That was before a racist extremist opened fire at a hookah bar Wednesday night, killing nine mostly young people in Germany’s worst attack in recent memory.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Roger Stone Is Sentenced to Over 3 Years in Prison
articles.snippet: The sentencing played out amid extraordinary upheaval at the Justice Department and a virtual standoff between the president and the attorney general.
articles.abstract: The sentencing played out amid extraordinary upheaval at the Justice Department and a virtual standoff between the president and the attorney general.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Roger J. Stone Jr., a longtime friend and adviser of President Trump, was sentenced Thursday to more than three years in prison in a politically fraught case that put the president at odds with his attorney general, stirred widespread consternation in the Justice Department and provoked the judge in the case to denounce pressure on the justice system.

articles.headline: Clicking Buy on Amazon? It’s Trying to Prevent a Coronavirus Caveat
articles.snippet: The Everything Store, which stocks more than 100 million items, is working to avoid disruptions in its supply chain.
articles.abstract: The Everything Store, which stocks more than 100 million items, is working to avoid disruptions in its supply chain.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — What if the Everything Store couldn’t sell everything because of disruptions from the coronavirus?
articles.byline: By Karen Weise and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Morgan Stanley to Buy E-Trade, Linking Wall Street and Main Street
articles.snippet: The $13 billion deal will give a powerful Wall Street firm control of a major presence in the world of online brokerage firms.
articles.abstract: The $13 billion deal will give a powerful Wall Street firm control of a major presence in the world of online brokerage firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley is betting its future on Main Street.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced, Kate Kelly and Emily Flitter

articles.headline: Victoria’s Secret Sale Caps End of Wexner’s Retail Empire
articles.snippet: Leslie Wexner, who built L Brands into a retailing force, had come under scrutiny for his ties to the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein.
articles.abstract: Leslie Wexner, who built L Brands into a retailing force, had come under scrutiny for his ties to the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades Leslie H. Wexner helped shape the modern shopping mall, his brands populating the space between department stores — Victoria’s Secret, Abercrombie & Fitch, Express, Bath & Body Works and more.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: As China Fights the Coronavirus, Some Say It Has Gone Too Far
articles.snippet: Some Chinese business figures are taking an unusual public stand, saying the containment efforts threaten to strangle the economy if applied too broadly.
articles.abstract: Some Chinese business figures are taking an unusual public stand, saying the containment efforts threaten to strangle the economy if applied too broadly.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China’s business leaders know better than to argue with Beijing. Leave the politics to the Communist Party, they long ago concluded, and the government will let them make money in peace.
